comments.comment: What are you so proud of? You will be the laborer who works for minimum wage for 6 day per week and 12 hours per day.
@kasun, Cheenunta copy karalla ahasyaana hadanna mollei thiyanawa! Apey uwunta MINNIMARANNA, HORRAKANNA missuk wenna kissima dukshataawayuk nahanei!
China must be powerful to offset unjust US foreign policy and excessive meddling to gain political advantages which does not value faith: Aukus.
Suppose! if China replace in lieu of USA playing now? what will be the end up? results will be more worse.

China is a dangerous place, not the Chinese people but the CCP. There is no democracy in China and the country is run based on rigid communist doctrine. There is no space for objection, criticism or dialogue. The Chinese policy is based on developing routes that will allow them to sell sub-standard goods all around the world. The New Silk Route is very much true and they are expanding their power and influence in the Asian region as well as in Africa ( both places full of corrupted politicians). China will invest heavily in other countries mainly for infrastructure development. Once the repayments have been defaulted, china takes over the asset and controls the operation as well as the revenue. In other words a country will become compelled to hand-over assets to China. Once this happens, China will use that to strengthen the geopolitical influence and move to the next asset they can conquer. West, quite correctly, is concerned about this influence and similar to USSR, at somepoint in the future, China will be disintegrated to small pieces. This will happen once the frustration of the general Chinese public becomes the driving force for change. When the disintegration happens, Sri Lanka will become something similar to an old Russian State that will be ignored by the west. Power shift from West to East is slowing down and will only be retained in countries that have aligned with the west.

To Zodiac: As my one and only reply I would like to observe following: Since Sri Lanka had been a colony of the Brits proceeded by the Dutch and the Portuguese, it is quite evident that considerable amount of people still venerate them with an awe, despite the atrocities they committed, with an illusionary democratic claim (not literally).  With regard to dialog: negotiated ‚Äì agreed ‚Äì executed but Aukus had gone berserk. Is breaking trust among alliances democratic? Winning hearts and minds of people in Iraq. Having that pretext, invading Iraq for having WMDs, is it democratic? Using chemical weapons in Vietnam and dropping atomic bombs on Japan when the war is 95% is over I suppose is democratic too.
